author: barnabemonnot
content:
Ok you're saying in the worst-case of a relay/builder that doesn't play timing games and that commits the winning block at `t = 0s`, then the maximum between payload committed and proposer signature received is 2s instead of 4s. I can see it happen in one of two cases:
- If the proposer is not playing timing games, they make the `getHeader` call at `t = 0s` and by `t = 0.9s`, they select the highest bid they have received and return the signed bid to the corresponding relay. Then the relay for some reason may withhold the payload until the last possible moment to release it (I don't think this is their behaviour broadly today), meaning the payload is published by `t = 4s` in the worst-case. This seems equivalent to ePBS with the payload reveal at `t = 4s`.
- If the proposer is playing timing games but they are calling a relay that is not playing games, say the proposer calls `getHeader` at `t = 2s` and by `t = 2.9s` they receive all bids from the queried relays, then they may be receiving a bid from a non-timing-games-playing relay that committed their payload at `t = 0s`. If the proposer chooses that bid (because it's the highest), then yes there is an interval of time between winning block committed and winning bid issued that could be longer than `2s`.

So I agree that the worst-case is essentially the same, and with 2s deadline you have a stronger upper bound on the "time between winning block committed and winning bid issued" in ePBS than in today's world for the second case (but then you have the same payload reveal deadline anyways). The concern is that the critical path in ePBS now includes, *even if mev-boost is used to bypass it*, the proposer needing to release their beacon payload first and the builder waiting for seeing the payload be well-attested enough to release the execution payload. This may not be the case if mev-boost under ePBS also places with the relay the responsibility of broadcasting the beacon payload, then the relay may be more confident

author: potuz
content: I think you continue to add time to count attestations when you should not. The builder does not need to count them. The builder gets the exact same unbundling safety as today without counting a single attestation and just releasing the Payload right after the attestation deadline, even if it's seen the block earlier

author: potuz
content: The "counting attestations" part is not in the protocol, it should not be added nor accounted for when we set the timelines for PTC
